review.title: A Reinforcement Learning Approach to Weaning of Mechanical Ventilation in Intensive Care Units
review.abstract: The management of invasive mechanical ventilation, and the regulation of sedation and analgesia during ventilation, constitutes a major part of the care of patients admitted to intensive care units. Both prolonged dependence on mechanical ventilation and premature extubation are associated with increased risk of complications and higher hospital costs, but clinical opinion on the best protocol for weaning patients off of a ventilator varies. This work aims to develop a decision support tool that uses available patient information to predict time-to-extubation readiness and to recommend a personalized regime of sedation dosage and ventilator support. To this end, we use off-policy reinforcement learning algorithms to determine the best action at a given patient state from sub-optimal historical ICU data. We compare treatment policies from fitted Q-iteration with extremely randomized trees and with feedforward neural networks, and demonstrate that the policies learnt show promise in recommending weaning protocols with improved outcomes, in terms of minimizing rates of reintubation and regulating physiological stability.

sections.text: The management of invasive mechanical ventilation and the regulation of sedation and analgesia during ventilation represent a large part of the care of patients admitted to ICU. Both prolonged dependence on mechanical ventilation and premature extubation are associated with increased risk of complications and higher hospital costs, but the clinical assessment of the best protocol for weaning from a ventilator varies. To this end, we are using non-political learning algorithms to develop a decision support tool that uses available patient information to predict the time to the excubation and recommend a personalized regimen of sedation dosing and ventilation support. To this end, we are using non-political learning algorithms to determine the best action in a given patient state based on suboptimal historical data in ICU. We are comparing adapted quality management policies with extremely randomized trees and associated neural networks, and showing that the strategies learned in ICU are promising when it comes to improving physiological stability.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We have one of the most widespread interventions in the admission of patients to ICU: about 40% of ICU patients are supported by invasive mechanical ventilation systems at a specified time so that they are able to treat themselves and their patients better. These are typically patients with acute respiratory distress or reduced lung function caused by some underlying conditions such as pneumonia, sepsis or heart disease, or cases where respiration becomes necessary due to neurological disorders, impaired consciousness or weakness following major operations. As advances in health care make it possible to survive critical diseases or operations, the need for mechanical ventilation during recovery is risky. Coupled with ventilation in the care of these patients, sedimented sediposition and analgesia are critical to maintaining physiological stability and control of patients.

sections.heading: 3.1 Critical Care Data
sections.text: We use the Multi-Parameter Intelligent Monitoring in Intensive Care (MIMIC III) database (Johnson et al. [2016]), a freely available source of de-identified critical care data for 53,423 adult admissions and 7,870 newborns. The data includes patient demographics, time-stamped measurements from monitoring vital organs at bed, administration of fluids and medications, results from laboratory tests, observations and notes presented by care providers, as well as diagnoses, procedures and billing prescriptions. We extract from this database a series of 8,860 admissions from 8,182 unique adult patients undergoing invasive ventilation. To train and test our discontinuation policy, we filter only those admissions where the patient has been kept under ventilation or support for more than 24 hours. This allows us to exclude the majority of episodes of routine ventilation after surgery that consists of the risk of an undesired withdrawal.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Preprocessing using Gaussian Processes
sections.text: Vital and laboratory measurements in ICU data can be irregular, sparse, and error prone. Non-invasive measurements such as heart rate or respiratory rate are only taken every few hours, while tests for arterial pH or oxygen pressure (when we have multiple measurements within an hour) and the use of sample-and-hold interpolation signals to imply subsequent missing values. Patient status - and thus the need to update sedation or ventilation management - can change within the space of an hour, and naive methods of interpolation are unlikely to provide the accuracy needed at higher time resolutions. We are therefore exploring ways to implement patient states that can allow more precise policy assessments.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Results
sections.text: After extracting relevant ventilation episodes from ICU approvals, each episode is treated in the MIMIC III database as an episode system with thousands of Q-Q meshes, and we split these into training and test data, giving us a total of 1,800 different approvals in our training set and 664 approvals in our test set. We interpolate the time vital measurements using Gaussian processes or sample-and-hold interpolation, which we perform in 10-minute intervals, resulting in yields in the order of 1.5 million one-step transitions in the training set, each transition being a 32-dimensional representation of patient statutes. As a baseline, we have applied Q-Learning to the training data to capture the continuous states that train functional approximation using a three-layer feedback forward neural network. The network is exercised using Adam, a more efficient, a kingstoic and an optimizer.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a data-driven approach to optimizing the weaning of patients in ICU. We model patient admissions such as Markov decision-making processes and develop novel representations of the problem state, scope of action, and reward function within this framework. Reinforcement learning with customized Q-iteration using various regressors is then used to learn a simple ventilator cessation policy from examples in historical ICU data. We show that the algorithm is capable of extracting meaningful indicators of patient readiness and recommending promising recommendations for excubation times and sedation levels that exceed clinical practice in terms of regulating vital and retubation systems.
